title: 107_hr2022
content: The "First-Time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 2001" aims to allow individuals to use funds from their retirement plans for first-time home purchases by removing tax and penalty impediments. Owners of individual retirement plans can direct trustees to invest plan funds in home equity or debt for themselves or family members who are first-time homebuyers. The "First-Time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 2001" allows retirement plans to invest in principal residences for first-time homebuyers. The "First-Time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 2001" allows retirement plans to invest in qualified home equity participation arrangements exempt from prohibited transaction rules under Section 4975 of the Internal Revenue Code. The "First-Time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 2001" permits retirement plans to engage in participation arrangements where the trustee acquires an ownership interest in a dwelling unit for a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. The arrangement must meet specific ownership interest requirements. The "First-Time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 2001" allows retirement plans to participate in arrangements where the trustee acquires a fee interest in a property for a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. The ownership interest must meet certain criteria, including full repayment upon sale, and cannot be used as security for a loan. An eligible participant is defined as an individual for whom an individual retirement plan is established. The "First-Time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 2001" allows retirement plans to participate in arrangements where the trustee acquires a fee interest in a property for a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. A first-time homebuyer is defined as an individual who had no present ownership interest in a principal residence during the 2-year period before the arrangement, and a qualified family member includes a child, parent, or grandparent of the eligible participant. The amendment allows for the determination of parent or grandparent eligibility for a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. It includes definitions for "acquisition" and "acquisition cost" and specifies that the effective date applies to arrangements entered into after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Loans used to acquire principal residences for first-time homebuyers. Loans used to purchase a home for first-time homebuyers are exempt from certain regulations under Section 408(e) of the Internal Revenue Code. This exemption applies to qualified home purchase loans made by an individual retirement plan, where the loan proceeds are used for the purchase of a home. The exemption under Section 408(e) of the Internal Revenue Code applies to qualified home purchase loans made by an individual retirement plan for first-time homebuyers. The loan must be used to acquire a dwelling unit to be used as the principal residence, require monthly interest payments, and full repayment within 15 years of acquisition or upon sale. The exemption under Section 408(e) of the Internal Revenue Code applies to qualified home purchase loans made by an individual retirement plan for first-time homebuyers. The loan must be used to acquire a dwelling unit to be used as the principal residence, require monthly interest payments, and full repayment within 15 years of acquisition or upon sale. The distribution of unpaid amounts from the plan to the individual is subject to certain conditions. The exemption under Section 408(e) of the Internal Revenue Code applies to qualified home purchase loans made by an individual retirement plan for first-time homebuyers. The loan must bear interest at a rate not less than 2 percentage points below, and not more than 2 percentage points above, the rate for comparable United States Treasury obligations on the loan date. The amount of borrowings not subject to certain limitations shall not exceed $10,000. No interest deduction is allowed for such loans. The exemption under Section 408(e) of the Internal Revenue Code allows qualified home purchase loans for first-time homebuyers. The loan must have interest rates within a specific range and borrowing limits. Definitions for terms like first-time homebuyer, acquisition, principal residence, and date of acquisition are provided. The Internal Revenue Code allows for qualified home purchase loans for first-time homebuyers, with specific criteria for interest rates and borrowing limits. Additionally, a new prohibited transaction is added regarding such loans. The amendments made by this section regarding qualified home purchase loans for first-time homebuyers shall apply to loans made after the date of the enactment of this Act.
